name: Marlene Dietrich: queering gender onscreen
description: Marlene Dietrich is an icon of queer style – from her proud bisexuality to her scandalous decision to wear a tuxedo on the red carpet. This constellation explores androgyny, gender non-conformity and drag on screen in the century since Dietrich's performance in Morocco (1930).

key_work.title: Flipping dress codes and gender expectations
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: Both Marlene Dietrich and Billy Porter have used their star personas to transcend the binary and fight for women’s and LGBTQIA+ rights, both on and off the screen.

start.title: Victor/Victoria
start.creator_credit: Blake Edwards, Tony Adams, Ladbroke Entertainment and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
start.brief_description: Sparkling, ultra-sophisticated entertainment from Blake Edwards. This story is based on a 1933 German comedy film “Viktor und Viktoria” written and directed by Rheinhold Schunzel. Set in Paris in 1934, it is the tale of a down-on-her luck chanteuse, played by Julie Andrews. Also suffering a temporary career lapse is tres gai nightclub entertainer (Robert Preston), who remakes her as a man who in short order becomes celebrated as Paris’s foremost female impersonator. In the process she snags the attentions of a Chicago nightclub owner (James Garner). He, however, has a small problem - is it a he or a she who has stolen his heart? 1982 Academy Award for Best Original Score (Henry Mancini). Academy Award nominations for Best Actress (Julie Andrews), Supporting Actor (Robert Preston), Supporting Actress (Lesley Anne Warren), Screenplay Adaptation, Costume Design and Art Direction.

links.description: The drag performance in Victor/Victoria (1982) has a local analogue. Carlotta (2014) is based on the life story of legendary trans actress and singer, Carlotta, who came to fame as the star of Sydney cabaret drag act Les Girls, a largely male troupe of ‘female impersonators.’

links.description: Performances like Carlotta’s draw on decades of creative gender performance by Black and Latinx LGBTQIA+ communities. Pose (2018) celebrates New York’s drag and ballroom culture of the 80s and 90s, breaking ground with the largest ever cast of trans actors on a scripted TV show.

links.description: Unlike their performance in The Politician (2019), Theo Germaine’s role in Work in Progress is deeply invested in trans experience. The series is a love story between two gender non-conforming characters: a trans man called Chris (Germaine) and an older, self-identified fat queer dyke (Abby McEnany), exploring the contours of queer gender dynamics.

start.title: Morocco
start.creator_credit: Josef von Sternberg, Hector Turnbull, Paramount, Benno Vigny and Jules Furthman
start.brief_description: The Foreign Legion marches into Mogador with booze and women in mind just as singer Amy Jolly arrives from Paris to work at Lo Tinto’s cabaret. That night, insouciant legionnaire Tom Brown catches her inimitably seductive, tuxedo-clad act.

links.description: The thirties was an exciting time for gender play on screen, from Morocco (1930) to German film Victor/Victoria (1933). Victor/Victoria was remade in English in 1982, starring Julie Andrews as a cisgender woman who poses as a male drag queen, leading to queer romantic confusion.
